Caption: Figure 19: Pruning Rewritings with Empty Results, Jena TDB
Mention:
already observed from their comparison in 4store (Figures 4
and 6 in Section 4).
The comparison for the individual optimization techniques
(SQR vs. OSQR-M with merger in Figure 18, SQR vs. OSQR-P
with pruning of empty results in Figure 19, and SQR vs.
OSQR-R with reordering in Figure 20) in Jena TDB are also
consistent with the observations from 4store, showing the
benefit of the individual optimization components we have
designed. The only exception is the running time compari-
son between SQR and OSQR-M in Jena TDB in Figure 18(b).
We do not observe a significant difference between the two,
in comparison to the result from 4store in Figure 8. We artic-
ulate that Jena TDB query engine implements some form of
merging (which is not available in 4store) and therefore the
performance of SQR and OSQR-M is similar in this case. Nev-
ertheless, Jena TDB has neither detection of empty rewrit-
ings, nor does it re-order predicates for efficient pruning of
empty rewritings, and therefore the remaining figures show
identical trends with 4store.
The pleasant surprise by the difference between 4store and
Jena TDB with regard to the merger optimization reinforces
the importance of our store-independent design principle.
In summary, our ultimate solution for SPARQL query rewiring
over multiple views, Algorithm OSQR, exhibits superior effi-
ciency and robustness in practice. Our extensive experimen-
tal results from two popular RDF stores convincingly and
consistently show that OSQR has good efficiency in practice,
from rewriting to the end of query execution, over tens to
hundred of views in RDF stores with 10 million triples.
